content.raw:
It's fine with me; it's just nice to know the convention. To be clear, the Iface functions added here are using `lowerCamelCase`, while class names and member functions use `UpperCamelCase` and the old-style Iface functions use `lower_underscore`.

The [Google style guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/cppguide.html#Function_Names) also proposes using underscores for "cheap functions", though they also seem to use trailing underscores in member variables like ROS. I'm neutral on that as well.
content.html:
It's fine with me; it's just nice to know the convention. To be clear, the Iface functions added here are using lowerCamelCase, while class names and member functions use UpperCamelCase and the old-style Iface functions use lower_underscore.

The Google style guide also proposes using underscores for "cheap functions", though they also seem to use trailing underscores in member variables like ROS. I'm neutral on that as well.

content.raw: No worries. I'm leaning toward greater consistency within Gazebo and across our various repositories. Normally, every class and member function uses camel case. Underscores were sprinkled inconsistently for C-style or global functions. Does that sound good to you?
content.html: No worries. I'm leaning toward greater consistency within Gazebo and across our various repositories. Normally, every class and member function uses camel case. Underscores were sprinkled inconsistently for C-style or global functions. Does that sound good to you?

content.raw: Sorry I'm a little late to this discussion; I'm curious what you mean by incorrect. Naming conventions are a style convention. We tend to follow your lead on the gazebo style guide; has lowerCamelCase vs underscores been a recent change in your thinking?
content.html: Sorry I'm a little late to this discussion; I'm curious what you mean by incorrect. Naming conventions are a style convention. We tend to follow your lead on the gazebo style guide; has lowerCamelCase vs underscores been a recent change in your thinking?

content.html: I'll merge this today to unblock a contractual obligation.

content.raw:
check copying / moving file to the same path? e.g. 

~~~
EXPECT_FALSE(common::copyFile("test3.tmp", "test3.tmp"));
~~~
content.html:
check copying / moving file to the same path? e.g. 

EXPECT_FALSE(common::copyFile("test3.tmp", "test3.tmp"));

How about checking that the content of test2.tmp is the same as test1.tmp?

std::ofstream tmpOut("test.tmp");
std::string data = "Output\n";
tmpOut << data;
tmpOut.close();

common::copyFile("test.tmp", "test2.tmp");
EXPECT_TRUE(common::exists("test.tmp"));
EXPECT_TRUE(common::exists("test2.tmp"));

std::ifstream ifs("test2.tmp");
std::string content((std::istreambuf_iterator<char>(ifs) ),
  (std::istreambuf_iterator<char>()));
EXPECT_EQ(content, data);

We could do a similar thing after common::moveFile().

How about checking that if you try to copy/move a directory (instead of a file) the operation fails and no new file/directory is created.

EXPECT_FALSE(common::copyFile(common::cwd(), "otherDir/"));
EXPECT_TRUE(!common::exists("otherDir/"));

EXPECT_FALSE(common::moveFile(common::cwd(), "anotherDir/"));
EXPECT_TRUE(!common::exists("anotherDir/"));

How about checking that if you try to copy/move a file with an incorrect source or destination path, the operation should fail and no files should be created?

EXPECT_FALSE(common::copyFile("__wrong__.tmp", "test2.tmp"));
EXPECT_TRUE(!common::exists("test2.tmp"));
EXPECT_FALSE(common::copyFile("test.tmp", "__wrong_dir__/__wrong__.tmp"));
EXPECT_TRUE(!common::exists("__wrong_dir__"));

EXPECT_FALSE(common::moveFile("__wrong__.tmp", "test3.tmp"));
EXPECT_TRUE(!common::exists("test3.tmp"));
EXPECT_FALSE(common::moveFile("test2.tmp", "__wrong_dir__/__wrong__.tmp"));
EXPECT_TRUE(!common::exists("__wrong_dir__"));

content.raw: Is this going to create the destination file even if the source file doesn't exist?
content.html: Is this going to create the destination file even if the source file doesn't exist?

content.html: EXPECT_TRUE?
